description:
Mythimna impura is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae, commonly known as the "smoky wainscot." It is a small to medium-sized moth with a wingspan of approximately 30-35 millimeters.

The adult moth has grayish-brown wings with indistinct markings, giving it a generally drab and inconspicuous appearance. The hindwings are typically pale gray or off-white. The body is also grayish-brown in color.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Mythimna impura are typically greenish-brown or grayish-brown in color, with a distinctive dark head capsule. They feed on various grasses and sedges as their primary food sources.

The species is widely distributed across Europe and parts of Asia, inhabiting a range of habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and wetland areas. It is generally considered a common and widespread species within its native range.

The life cycle of Mythimna impura involves the moth laying eggs, which hatch into larvae that feed and grow, eventually pupating and emerging as adult moths. The species may have multiple generations per year, depending on local climatic conditions.
